name: De Barsy Syndrome
description: De Barsy syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by cutis laxa (loose, wrinkled skin), growth retardation, intellectual disability, progeroid features (premature aging), and distinctive facial features. The severity of symptoms can vary among affected individuals. Several subtypes exist, each linked to different gene mutations.
symptoms: Distinctive facial features (e.g., large ears, prominent eyes)
prognosis: The prognosis varies depending on the severity of the symptoms and the specific genetic mutation. Some individuals may have a significantly shortened lifespan due to complications such as respiratory failure or cardiac issues.
lifeExpectancy: Variable, ranging from infancy to adulthood, depending on the severity and complications.
diagnosticMethods: Genetic testing (whole exome sequencing, targeted gene sequencing)
keyResearchCenters: Academic medical centers with genetics departments

patientOrganizations.name: Genetic and Rare Diseases Information Center (GARD)

eli5Summary: Imagine your skin is like a loose, wrinkly shirt that's too big. Kids with De Barsy Syndrome have skin like that, and they might grow slower and have a harder time learning. It's like their bodies are aging a little faster than they should.
clinicalSummary: De Barsy syndrome encompasses a group of rare, autosomal recessive disorders characterized by cutis laxa, growth retardation, intellectual disability, and progeroid features. The underlying pathology involves mutations in genes related to endoplasmic reticulum stress response and protein glycosylation, leading to abnormal collagen and elastin synthesis. Clinical presentation includes generalized cutis laxa, particularly evident on the face and extremities, skeletal abnormalities, cataracts, and neurodevelopmental delays. Diagnosis is based on clinical findings, skin biopsy, and genetic testing. Management is primarily supportive, addressing specific complications such as respiratory issues, feeding difficulties, and visual impairment. Prognosis is variable, with some individuals experiencing significant morbidity and mortality in early childhood.
historicalBackground: De Barsy syndrome was first described by De Barsy et al. in 1968. Initial reports focused on the clinical features of cutis laxa, growth retardation, and progeroid appearance. Subsequent research has identified various genetic mutations associated with the syndrome, leading to a better understanding of its molecular basis and heterogeneity.

recentBreakthroughs.title: Identification of ATP6V0A2 mutations in De Barsy Syndrome
recentBreakthroughs.description: Research identified mutations in the ATP6V0A2 gene as a cause of De Barsy Syndrome, providing insights into the genetic basis of the disease and potential targets for future therapies.

recentBreakthroughs.title: Further delineation of the genetic landscape of autosomal recessive cutis laxa
recentBreakthroughs.description: Studies have expanded the understanding of the genetic heterogeneity of De Barsy syndrome and related cutis laxa syndromes, identifying additional genes and mutations associated with the condition.
